clinical_study.brief_title: Trial Comparing Single Versus Double Incision to Repair Distal Bicep Tendon Ruptures
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Control Trial Comparing Single Incision Versus Double Incision Surgery to Repair Distal Bicep Tendon Ruptures

lead_sponsor.agency: Hand and Upper Limb Clinic, Canada

clinical_study.source: Hand and Upper Limb Clinic, Canada

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study to to determine whether a single incision technique or a double incision technique is more effective in the surgical treatment of distal bicep tendon ruptures. Patients will be randomized to one of the two techniques upon consenting to the study. Prior to surgery patients will have their elbow flexion, extension, pronation, and supination strength measured. Elbow Range of motion will also be measured in each of these four movements. A number of subjective questionnaires will also be administered to the patient prior to surgery. The identical objective tests and subjective questionnaires will be completed by the patient at intervals of three months, six months, one year, and two years following their surgery. Additional information from patients clinical visits may also be collected throughout the study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Complete rupture of the Distal Bicep tendon
- Acute bicep tendon rupture (< 10 days since rupture)
- 18 years of age and older
Exclusion Criteria:
- Partial rupture of the Distal Bicep tendon
- Chronic bicep tendon Ruptures (>10 days since rupture)
- Under 18 years of age
